items.title: Canada to drop counter-tariffs on some US goods one day after call with Trump
items.standfirst: Mark Carney says change will go into effect on 1 September but tariffs on steel, aluminum and autos will remainCanada will drop its counter-tariffs on some American goods in the coming days, Mark Carney has said, as the country’s prime minister looks to end a protracted trade war with longtime ally the United States.From 1 September, the Canadian government will remove some levies on US goods that comply with the North American free-trade pact, a move meant to “match” how the White House treated Canadian goods. Levies on steel, aluminum and autos will remain in place. Continue reading...
items.content: Mark Carney says change will go into effect on 1 September but tariffs on steel, aluminum and autos will remainCanada will drop its counter-tariffs on some American goods in the coming days, Mark Carney has said, as the country’s prime minister looks to end a protracted trade war with longtime ally the United States.From 1 September, the Canadian government will remove some levies on US goods that comply with the North American free-trade pact, a move meant to “match” how the White House treated Canadian goods. Levies on steel, aluminum and autos will remain in place. Continue reading...

items.title: Fed chair Jerome Powell signals interest rate cuts amid Trump attacks
items.standfirst: Powell – whom Trump has urged to resign – addressed ‘challenging’ dichotomy of economic risks, including tariffsThe Federal Reserve is gearing up to resume cuts to interest rates, its chair, Jerome Powell, has signaled, as he warned that Donald Trump’s tariffs and immigration crackdown had roiled the global economy and hit the US workforce.For months, Powell has ignored demands from the president to cut interest rates and defied Trump’s calls to resign. But as the president ramps up his extraordinary attack on the Fed’s independence, Powell suggested on Friday that central bank officials are considering a rate cut. Continue reading...
items.content: Powell – whom Trump has urged to resign – addressed ‘challenging’ dichotomy of economic risks, including tariffsThe Federal Reserve is gearing up to resume cuts to interest rates, its chair, Jerome Powell, has signaled, as he warned that Donald Trump’s tariffs and immigration crackdown had roiled the global economy and hit the US workforce.For months, Powell has ignored demands from the president to cut interest rates and defied Trump’s calls to resign. But as the president ramps up his extraordinary attack on the Fed’s independence, Powell suggested on Friday that central bank officials are considering a rate cut. Continue reading...

items.title: FBI searches John Bolton's house
items.standfirst: The FBI confirmed it that it searched former national security adviser John Bolton's house early Friday morning.
items.content: The FBI confirmed it that it searched former national security adviser John Bolton's house early Friday morning.

items.title: Latest news on FBI searching John Bolton's home, office
items.standfirst: The FBI raided John Bolton's home and office, CBS News confirmed. Bolton was President Trump's national security adviser during his first term at the White House. CBS News' Robert Costa reports.
items.content: The FBI raided John Bolton's home and office, CBS News confirmed. Bolton was President Trump's national security adviser during his first term at the White House. CBS News' Robert Costa reports.

items.title: Trump reacts to Canada reversing retaliatory tariffs, takes questions at White House
items.standfirst: President Trump took questions from the Oval Office on Canada, announcing a reversal on its retaliatory tariffs against the U.S. Mr. Trump also weighed in on the Russia-Ukraine war, the FBI raiding John Bolton's home, and his crime takeover in Washington, D.C. CBS News' Willie James Inman reports.
items.content: President Trump took questions from the Oval Office on Canada, announcing a reversal on its retaliatory tariffs against the U.S. Mr. Trump also weighed in on the Russia-Ukraine war, the FBI raiding John Bolton's home, and his crime takeover in Washington, D.C. CBS News' Willie James Inman reports.

items.content: The FBI has raided the home of John Bolton, the former national security adviser to Donald Trump who has since become a staunch critic of the US president.

items.title: FBI searches home of Trump’s former adviser and current critic John Bolton
items.standfirst: John Bolton served as national security adviser during US President Donald Trump’s first term before quitting and facing scrutiny over a book he wrote about his time in government. The FBI raided his Maryland home Friday as part of a probe into the handling of classified records.
items.content: John Bolton served as national security adviser during US President Donald Trump’s first term before quitting and facing scrutiny over a book he wrote about his time in government. The FBI raided his Maryland home Friday as part of a probe into the handling of classified records.

clusters.title: Civilians flee Israel’s Gaza City offensive

items.title: Civilians flee Israel’s Gaza City offensive
items.standfirst: With famine officially declared in northern Gaza, and Israel aiming for full military occupation, civilians are being displaced once again, heading south in an effort to avoid the attacks.
items.content: With famine officially declared in northern Gaza, and Israel aiming for full military occupation, civilians are being displaced once again, heading south in an effort to avoid the attacks.

items.content: A UN classification system used to determine access to food has officially declared famine in Gaza.

items.content: A U.N.-backed panel of experts has declared that northern Gaza is suffering from famine. And, the DOJ is expected to release to Congress the first wave of documents related to its Jeffrey Epstein probe.(Image credit: Eyad Baba)

items.content: The UN-backed IPC says more than half a million Palestinians facing catastrophic famine conditions amid Israel's war.

items.standfirst: A UN-backed body confirms famine in Gaza Strip and surrounding areas, and says half a million are facing "catastrophic" conditions.
items.content: A UN-backed body confirms famine in Gaza Strip and surrounding areas, and says half a million are facing "catastrophic" conditions.

items.title: UN declares famine in Gaza, over 500,000 affected
items.standfirst: The United Nations confirmed on Thursday a state of famine in Gaza, with more than half a million people affected. Israel, however, disputes the report, claiming IPC figures are based on fake Hamas sources.
items.content: The United Nations confirmed on Thursday a state of famine in Gaza, with more than half a million people affected. Israel, however, disputes the report, claiming IPC figures are based on fake Hamas sources.

items.title: Food crisis group declares first-ever famine in Gaza
items.standfirst: The IPC, a global body that monitors hunger crises, says 22 months of war in Gaza have left half a million people facing "starvation, destitution and death." Israel calls it "lies."
items.content: The IPC, a global body that monitors hunger crises, says 22 months of war in Gaza have left half a million people facing "starvation, destitution and death." Israel calls it "lies."

items.title: 'My youngest child doesn't know what fruit tastes like': Gaza residents on famine
items.standfirst: A UN-backed body says more than half a million people across Gaza are facing "starvation, destitution and death".
items.content: A UN-backed body says more than half a million people across Gaza are facing "starvation, destitution and death".

items.title: What has led to a famine being confirmed in Gaza?
items.standfirst: The UN-backed IPC has found that Gaza now faces famine after 22 months of Israel's war on the Palestinian territory.
items.content: The UN-backed IPC has found that Gaza now faces famine after 22 months of Israel's war on the Palestinian territory.

items.title: UN's IPC declares famine in Gaza, Israel denies
items.standfirst: Israel rejected a UN-backed report confirming famine in Gaza, calling the findings false and based on “Hamas lies.” The report had stated that famine now affects Gaza City, covering about 20% of the Gaza Strip. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky has some more details from Jerusalem.
items.content: Israel rejected a UN-backed report confirming famine in Gaza, calling the findings false and based on “Hamas lies.” The report had stated that famine now affects Gaza City, covering about 20% of the Gaza Strip. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky has some more details from Jerusalem.

A UN-backed body confirms famine in Gaza and surrounding areas.
The United Nations confirmed a state of famine in Gaza.

items.title: Russia’s Lavrov says agenda ‘not ready at all’ for Putin-Zelenskyy summit
items.standfirst: Russia's top diplomat Sergey Lavrov accuses Ukrainian President Zelenskyy of saying 'no to everything'.
items.content: Russia's top diplomat Sergey Lavrov accuses Ukrainian President Zelenskyy of saying 'no to everything'.

items.title: Russia's foreign minister says no Putin-Zelenskyy summit planned despite Trump's peace push
items.standfirst: Russia’s top diplomat said Friday that no meeting is planned between President Vladimir Putin and Ukraine’s Volodymyr Zelenskyy, casting new doubt on President Donald Trump’s push for a summit to end the war.“Putin is ready to meet with Zelenskyy when the agenda is ready for a summit, and this agenda is not ready at all,” Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov told NBC News’ “Meet the Press” moderator Kristen Welker in an exclusive interview

clusters.title: Colombia hit by deadly guerrilla attacks, at least 18 killed
clusters.neutral_headline: Deadly Guerrilla Attacks in Colombia Kill 18

items.title: Colombia hit by deadly guerrilla attacks, at least 18 killed
items.standfirst: Two attacks by dissident guerrilla groups in Colombia killed 18 people and injured dozens on Thursday. A truck bomb struck Cali, while a drone downed a police helicopter at a northern coca farm, worsening the country’s worst security crisis in decades and threatening fragile peace efforts ahead of next year’s elections.
items.content: Two attacks by dissident guerrilla groups in Colombia killed 18 people and injured dozens on Thursday. A truck bomb struck Cali, while a drone downed a police helicopter at a northern coca farm, worsening the country’s worst security crisis in decades and threatening fragile peace efforts ahead of next year’s elections.

items.title: In Colombia, two separate guerilla attacks kill 18
items.standfirst: Two attacks by dissident guerrilla groups killed 18 people and injured dozens in Colombia on Thursday. A truck bomb struck Cali, killing six and wounding more than 60, while a drone brought down a police helicopter at a coca farm in the north. The violence deepens Colombia’s worst security crisis in decades and threatens fragile peace efforts ahead of next year’s elections. FRANCE 24'- Juan Pablo Lucumi has more from our offices in Bogota.
items.content: Two attacks by dissident guerrilla groups killed 18 people and injured dozens in Colombia on Thursday. A truck bomb struck Cali, killing six and wounding more than 60, while a drone brought down a police helicopter at a coca farm in the north. The violence deepens Colombia’s worst security crisis in decades and threatens fragile peace efforts ahead of next year’s elections. FRANCE 24'- Juan Pablo Lucumi has more from our offices in Bogota.

items.title: US judge orders dismantling of Trump's 'Alligator Alcatraz'
items.standfirst: A US federal judge on Thursday blocked the Trump administration and Florida state authorities from sending any new migrants to the detention centre known as "Alligator Alcatraz" and ordered much of the facility to be dismantled, effectively shutting it down. Florida’s government quickly said it would appeal the ruling.

items.title: Iran, European powers to resume nuclear talks as 'snapback' sanctions loom
items.standfirst: Ahead of an August 31 deadline imposed by France, Britain and Germany, to trigger a "snapback" sanctions mechanism, Iran on Friday agreed to resume nuclear talks with the "E3" European countries next week. The Israel-Iran war in June has added pressure on the European powers to reach a diplomatic solution to the Iranian nuclear issue.

clusters.title: Noel Clarke loses libel case against Guardian over sexual misconduct investigation

items.title: Noel Clarke loses libel case against Guardian over sexual misconduct investigation
items.standfirst: High court rejects actor’s claim that accusations against him by more than 20 women were false and part of a conspiracy• Key findings from the Noel Clarke libel caseThe Guardian has successfully defended a libel action brought by Noel Clarke over an investigation in which the actor was accused of sexual misconduct by more than 20 women.In a landmark high court judgment handed down on Friday, Mrs Justice Steyn rejected Clarke’s claims, and ruled the newspaper had succeeded in both its defences: of truth and public interest. Continue reading...

Continue reading...
